query.result:
**English:**
1 A loud clap of thunder broke my deep sleep, 2 so that I started up 3 like a person who is forcibly awakened;
4 and with my rested eyes I looked around, 5 standing up straight and gazing intently 6 to find out where I was.
**Old English:**
1 Wearð me ðæs slæpes swutol on heafde 2 ðunor on lyfte, ða ic onwoc hrade 3 swa ðegn byð on fyrde ðonne he gefricgeð 4 hlude hlemm on here, scearpne ord scritman 5 wigend weccean, and ða wulf hleoðoð 6 yrre on ðære nihte, norðan winda 7 hrindeð hrusan, hreosende snaw 8 fealleð on foldan, fioloð ða ceaster 9 burgum beblidene, ða ðe beorn ne mot 10 eðelwynna brucan.
(This is a poetic translation of the passage into Old English, as there is no direct equivalent to the Italian text in Old English literature.)

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 Vero è che ’n su la proda mi trovai 8 de la valle d’abisso dolorosa 9 che ’ntrono accoglie d’infiniti guai.
query.result:
**English:**
7 It is true that I found myself on the edge 8 of the dolorous valley of the abyss, 9 which gathers within it infinite woes.
**Old English:**
7 Soð is ðæt ic me fand on ðære strande 8 ðære earmlican deopan dales, 9 ðe on hire fæðme unrim gerîmes hæfð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Oscura e profonda era e nebulosa 11 tanto che, per ficcar lo viso a fondo, 12 io non vi discernea alcuna cosa.
query.result:
**English:**
10 Dark and deep and cloudy it was, 11 so much that, peering into its depths, 12 I could not make out anything.
**Old English:**
10 Dim wæs and deop and ðuster ðær, 11 swa ðæt ðæs leoman ne meahte on ðam grund 12 geseon hwæt ðær wæs innan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 «Or discendiam qua giù nel cieco mondo», 14 cominciò il poeta tutto smorto. 15 «Io sarò primo, e tu sarai secondo».
query.result:
**English:**
13 "Now let us descend here into the blind world," 14 began the poet, all pale. 15 "I will be first, and you will be second."
**Old English:**
13 "Nu wuton we ðisne steapan stigol 14 onginnan, ic beforan ðe, ðu me folga."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 E io, che del color mi fui accorto, 17 dissi: «Come verrò, se tu paventi 18 che suoli al mio dubbiare esser conforto?».
query.result:
**English:**
16 And I, who had noticed my color, 17 said: "How shall I come, if you are afraid, 18 you who are accustomed to be a comfort to my doubts?".
**Old English:**
16 And ic ðe ðæs heowes oncniowe, 17 cwæð: "Hu mæg ic ðider cuman, gif ðu ondrædest, 18 ðe ðeah wære min hyht on ðinum hæle?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Ed elli a me: «L’angoscia de le genti 20 che son qua giù, nel viso mi dipigne 21 quella pietà che tu per tema senti.
query.result:
**English:**
19 And he to me: "The anguish of the people 20 who are down here, in my face paints 21 that pity which you feel through fear.
**Old English:**
19 And he to me: "Þæs folces angris 20 ðe sindon her niðe, on ðam ansyne minum 21 ða mildheortnesse ðe ðu ðurh ege hæfst.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Andiam, ché la via lunga ne sospigne». 23 Così si mise e così mi fé intrare 24 nel primo cerchio che l’abisso cigne.
query.result:
**English:**
22 Let us go, for the long road urges us on." 23 Thus he moved, and thus he made me enter 24 into the first circle that the abyss encircles.
**Old English:**
22 Uton gangan, forðæm ðe ðeos lange weg us tyht." 23 Swa he hine gesette and swa he dyde ðæt ic eode 24 on ðone ærostan hring ðe ðone grund bewylgð.

**English:**
25 There, according to what I could hear, 26 there was never any weeping, but only sighs 27 that made the eternal air tremble;
28 this came from the pain without torment 29 that the crowds, which were many and great, 30 of infants and women and men had.
**Old English:**
25 Þær, swa ic gehyrde, næfre weop 26 butan suslum, ða ða sawle wunedon, 27 ða ðone ecan lyft onhreredon;
28 ðæt wæs geómlic thing ða ic ðær geseah 29 ða miclan menigu, ða ðær wæron, 30 cnihtas and wif and ða wælgrimman.
**Notes:**
* Line 25: "Quivi" (there) is translated as "Þær" in Old English. * Line 26: "non avea pianto mai che di sospiri" (there was never any weeping, but only sighs) is translated as "næfre weop butan suslum" (never any weeping, but only sighs) in Old English. * Line 27: "che l’aura etterna facevan tremare" (that made the eternal air tremble) is translated as "ða ða sawle wunedon, ða ðone ecan lyft onhreredon" (when the souls lamented, they made the eternal air tremble) in Old English. * Line 28: "ciò avvenia di duol sanza martìri" (this came from the pain without torment) is translated as "ðæt wæs geómlic thing ða ic ðær geseah" (that was a grievous thing that I saw there) in Old English. * Line 29: "ch’avean le turbe, ch’eran molte e grandi" (that the crowds, which were many and great) is translated as "ða miclan menigu, ða ðær wæron" (the great multitude that was there) in Old English. * Line 30: "d’infanti e di femmine e di viri" (of infants and women and men) is translated as "cnihtas and wif and ða wælgrimman" (children and women and the weary warriors) in Old English.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 Lo buon maestro a me: «Tu non dimandi 32 che spiriti son questi che tu vedi? 33 Or vo’ che sappi, innanzi che più andi,
34 ch’ei non peccaro; e s’elli hanno mercedi, 35 non basta, perché non ebber battesmo, 36 ch’è porta de la fede che tu credi;
37 e s’e’ furon dinanzi al cristianesmo, 38 non adorar debitamente a Dio: 39 e di questi cotai son io medesmo.
query.result:
**English:**
31 The good master said to me: "Do you not ask 32 what spirits these are that you see? 33 Now I want you to know, before you go any further,
34 that they did not sin; and if they have mercy, 35 it is not enough, because they did not receive baptism, 36 which is the gate of the faith that you believe in;
37 and if they were before Christianity, 38 they did not worship God properly: 39 and I myself am one of these.
**Old English:**
31 Se goda lareow to me: "Þu ne axast 32 hwylce gastas synd þas þe þu gesyhst? 33 Nu ic wille ðæt þu wite, ær þu firr ga,
34 ðæt hi nefre ne syngodon; and gif hi habbað mildheortnysse, 35 ne mæg hit genihtsumian, forðæm þe hi ne underfengon nænne fulluht, 36 se is duru ðæs geleaffulnesse þe þu gelyfst;
37 and gif hi wæron ær ðam Cristendome, 38 hi ne wurðodon God swa swa hi sceoldon: 39 and ic sylf eom an of ðam ilcan."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Per tai difetti, non per altro rio, 41 semo perduti, e sol di tanto offesi 42 che sanza speme vivemo in disio».
query.result:
**English:**
40 For these defects, not for any other evil, 41 we are lost, and only so much offended 42 that without hope we live in desire.
**Old English:**
40 For ðam gebrece, na for ðam oðrum leahtrum, 41 we synt forlorene, and swa ðeah ðæs geswencte, 42 ðæt we butan hyhte libbað on ðam gewilnungum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 Gran duol mi prese al cor quando lo ’ntesi, 44 però che gente di molto valore 45 conobbi che ’n quel limbo eran sospesi.
query.result:
**English:**
43 Great sorrow seized my heart when I heard it, 44 because I knew that people of great worth 45 were suspended in that limbo.
**Old English:**
43 Mearc sorgum wæs ða ða ic ðæt gehørde, 44 forðæm ic ðær geseah ða mænige men 45 ðe wæron on ðam wíte gebunden.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 «Dimmi, maestro mio, dimmi, segnore», 47 comincia’ io per voler esser certo 48 di quella fede che vince ogne errore:
49 «uscicci mai alcuno, o per suo merto 50 o per altrui, che poi fosse beato?».
query.result:
**English:**
46 "Tell me, my master, tell me, my lord," 47 I began, wanting to be certain 48 of that faith which conquers all error:
49 "Did anyone ever escape from here, either through his own merit 50 or through someone else's, who was then blessed?"
**Old English:**
46 "Saga me, lareow min, saga me, hlaford," 47 ongan ic ða sprecan, willende beon georn, 48 ðære geleafan ðe ofercuman mæg æghwylcne gedwolan:
49 "Wæs her æfre ænig monna, ðurh his agen ðing 50 oððe ðurh oðres mannes, ðe wære siððan eadig?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
51 E quei che ’ntese il mio parlar coverto,
52 rispuose: «Io era nuovo in questo stato, 53 quando ci vidi venire un possente, 54 con segno di vittoria coronato.
query.result:
**English:**
51 And he who understood my hidden speech,
52 replied: "I was new in this state, 53 when I saw a mighty one come here, 54 crowned with a sign of victory.
**Old English:**
51 And se ðe ðæt gehørde ðæt ic ðus dyde,
52 he andswarode: "Ic wæs niwe on ðissum stade, 53 ða ic ðær geseah cuman ðone micclan, 54 mid sigetacne getrymede.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 Trasseci l’ombra del primo parente, 56 d’Abèl suo figlio e quella di Noè, 57 di Moïsè legista e ubidente;
58 Abraàm patrïarca e Davìd re, 59 Israèl con lo padre e co’ suoi nati 60 e con Rachele, per cui tanto fé,
61 e altri molti, e feceli beati.
query.result:
**English:**
55 I drew forth the shade of our first parent, 56 of his son Abel, and of Noah, 57 of Moses, the lawgiver and obedient;
58 of the patriarch Abraham and King David, 59 of Israel with his father and his children, 60 and with Rachel, for whom he did so much,
61 and many others, and made them blessed.
**Old English:**
55 Ic ða ðæs frumsceaftes fæder onwrah, 56 Abeles his suna and Noes, 57 Moyses ðæs lareowes and ðæs gehyrsuman;
58 Abraham ðæs heahfæderes and Dauides ðæs cyninges, 59 Israhel mid his fæder and mid his bearnum 60 and mid Rachele, ðe he ða swiðe lufode,
61 and fela oðre, and geworhte ða eadige.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
62 E vo’ che sappi che, dinanzi ad essi, 63 spiriti umani non eran salvati».
64 Non lasciavam l’andar perch’ ei dicessi, 65 ma passavam la selva tuttavia, 66 la selva, dico, di spiriti spessi.
query.result:
**English:**
62 And you should know that, before them, 63 no human spirits were saved."
64 We did not stop walking because he said this, 65 but we continued through the forest, 66 the forest, I say, of thick spirits.
**Old English:**
62 And ðu scealt witan ðæt, ær ðæm, 63 nænigra manna sawla næron gehealdene."
64 Ne forleton we ðone gang for ðæm ðe he ðis sæde, 65 ac we ferdon ða ðurh ðone wudu forð, 66 ðone wudu, ic secge, ðara ðiccena gasta.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Non era lunga ancor la nostra via 68 di qua dal sonno, quand’ io vidi un foco 69 ch’emisperio di tenebre vincia.
query.result:
**English:**
67 Our way was not long from there 68 beyond sleep, when I saw a fire 69 that conquered a hemisphere of darkness.
**Old English:**
67 Nis ðæs færes fela 68 fram ðam slæpe, ða ic ðone leoman geseah 69 ðe ðone hæðenan heofon oferwlat.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 Di lungi n’eravamo ancora un poco, 71 ma non sì ch’io non discernessi in parte 72 ch’orrevol gente possedea quel loco.
query.result:
**English:**
70 We were still a little way off, 71 but not so far that I could not make out in part 72 that a rebellious people possessed that place.
**Old English:**
70 We wæron ða furðum sum fæc 71 ac ðeah ne wæs ðæt feor swa ðeah 72 ðæt ic ne gesawe ðær on sumre wisan 73 ðæt ðær folc unrihtwis wæs ðæs stowe gewealdend.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 «O tu ch’onori scïenzïa e arte, 74 questi chi son c’hanno cotanta onranza, 75 che dal modo de li altri li diparte?».
query.result:

73 "O you who honor knowledge and art, 74 who are these who have such great honor, 75 that it sets them apart from the others?"
**Old English:**
73 "Eala ðu ðe weorðast wisdom and cræft, 74 hwa sind ðas ðe habbað swylce micelne wurðmynt, 75 ðæt hit hi fram oðrum mannum todæleð?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 E quelli a me: «L’onrata nominanza 77 che di lor suona sù ne la tua vita, 78 grazïa acquista in ciel che sì li avanza».
query.result:
**English:**

**Old English:**
76 And ða to me: "Ðæt arwurðe lof 77 ðe of heom scyneð upp on ðinum life, 78 geearnað on heofonum ða gyfe ðe heom swa fremmeð."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Intanto voce fu per me udita: 80 «Onorate l’altissimo poeta; 81 l’ombra sua torna, ch’era dipartita».
query.result:
**English:**
79 In the meantime, a voice was heard by me: 80 "Honor the most high poet; 81 his shade returns, which had departed".
**Old English:**
79 Þa wearð min eare ðurh stefne gewreht: 80 "Weorða ðone hehstan heofones weard; 81 his gæst cymeð, seo ðe ær wæs gewiten".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 Poi che la voce fu restata e queta, 83 vidi quattro grand’ ombre a noi venire: 84 sembianz’ avevan né trista né lieta.
query.result:
**English:**
82 After the voice had ceased and was quiet, 83 I saw four great shades coming towards us: 84 their appearance was neither sad nor happy.
**Old English:**
82 Þa ða ða stefn wæs gestilled and gewunnen, 83 ða geseah ic feower micle sceadu to usweard cuman: 84 hiwum hi ne wæron ne sarige ne blide.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Lo buon maestro cominciò a dire: 86 «Mira colui con quella spada in mano, 87 che vien dinanzi ai tre sì come sire:
88 quelli è Omero poeta sovrano; 89 l’altro è Orazio satiro che vene; 90 Ovidio è ’l terzo, e l’ultimo Lucano.
query.result:
**English:**
85 The good master began to say: 86 "Look at the one with that sword in his hand, 87 who comes before the three like a lord:
88 that is Homer, the sovereign poet; 89 the other is Horace, the satirist, who comes; 90 Ovid is the third, and the last is Lucan.
**Old English:**
85 Se goda lareow ongan ða secgan: 86 "Loca ðone ðe ða sweord hafað on handa, 87 ðe ðam ðrim beforan gæð swa swa hlaford:
88 ðæt is Homerus se hehsta lareow; 89 se oðer is Oracius se deð stiðra leoða; 90 Ouidius is se ðridda, and se ytemesta Lucanus.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Però che ciascun meco si convene 92 nel nome che sonò la voce sola, 93 fannomi onore, e di ciò fanno bene».
query.result:
**English:**
91 Because each one of them agrees with me 92 in the name that the solitary voice resounded, 93 they do me honor, and they do well in that.
**Old English:**
91 Forðæm ðe ælc mid me geþafað 92 on ðam naman ðe ðæt ænlipige stefn hlynode, 93 ða doð hi me arwurðnesse, and ðæt hi wel doð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.

query.result:

**Old English:**
94 Þus ic ða geseah ða fægran scolu 95 ðæs hlafordes ðæs hehstan sangas 96 se ðe ofer ða oðre swa earn fleogeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Così andammo infino a la lumera, 104 parlando cose che ’l tacere è bello, 105 sì com’ era ’l parlar colà dov’ era.
query.result:
**English:**
103 Thus we went on until we reached the light, 104 speaking of things that it is good to keep silent about, 105 just as it was good to speak of them where we were.
**Old English:**
103 Þus we eodon forð oð ðæt we comon to ðære leohte, 104 sprecende ðinga ðe ðæt dysig is to secganne, 105 swa swa hit wæs ðær to sprecanne ðær hit wæs.

query.prompt:

**Old English:**
106 We comon ða to ðæs eadigan castles fót, 107 seofon siðon utan ymbefangen mid heán wealle, 108 utan ymbehworfen mid ðære fægran ea.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Questo passammo come terra dura; 110 per sette porte intrai con questi savi: 111 giugnemmo in prato di fresca verdura.

Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Genti v’eran con occhi tardi e gravi, 113 di grande autorità ne’ lor sembianti: 114 parlavan rado, con voci soavi.
query.result:

**Old English:**
112 Þær wæron men mid eagum dimmum and hefigum, 113 micelre anwealde on heora andwlitum: 114 spræcon seldan, mid stemnum luflicum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 Traemmoci così da l’un de’ canti, 116 in loco aperto, luminoso e alto, 117 sì che veder si potien tutti quanti.
query.result:
**English:**
115 We thus emerged from one of the banks, 116 into an open, bright, and lofty place, 117 so that we could see all of them.
**Old English:**
115 Þa comon we þus of ðam anan sidan, 116 on opene stowe, leoht and heah, 117 swa ðæt we mihton ealle ymb utan geseon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 Colà diritto, sovra ’l verde smalto, 119 mi fuor mostrati li spiriti magni, 120 che del vedere in me stesso m’essalto.
query.result:
**English:**

**Old English:**
118 Þær, rihte beforan, ofer ðone grene smæl, 119 wæron me gecyðede ða miclan gastas, 120 ðe ðæs gesyhðe on me selfum me up ahefð.

query.prompt:

**Old English:**

query.prompt:

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.

145 Io non posso ritrar di tutti a pieno, 146 però che sì mi caccia il lungo tema, 147 che molte volte al fatto il dir vien meno.
query.result:

query.result:

**Old English:**

query.prompt:

151 E vegno in parte ove non è che luca.
query.result:
**English:**

**Old English:**
151 And ic cume to ðære stowe ðær nis nan leoht.
